Raster: Raster data is a grid of pixels where each grid square has a single attribute value
Performs some simplification or generalizations based on average values within a square of the grid

One grid cell equals one unit. Every cell has a value. A cell has a given resolution, given as the cell size in ground units (such as square meters). Depending on what the goal or purpose is of the map, higher resolution of a grid may or may not be necessary.
Cell value; Cell size (resolution); Spatial reference (location information); Raster bands (stacking multiple grids of information)
Vector: Points (single location); Lines (a set of connected points); Polygons (area marked by enclosing lines)

Raster: Satellite images; Terrain maps; Land cover maps; elevation maps; disease incidence
Vector: Addresses (points); rivers or roads (lines); state or county jurisdiction (polygons)

Raster: Simple data structure; easy overlay; various kinds of spatial analysis; uniform size and shape; cheaper technology
Vector: Good representation of reality; compact data structure; topology can be descrived in a network; accurate graphics

Raster: Large amount of data; projection transformation is difficult; different scales between layers can be a nightmare; may lose information due to generalization
Vector: Complex data structures; simulation may be difficult; some spatial analysis is difficult
